name: The Jimmy Quiz / Test | 'Seinfeld' - Season 6 | 10 Questions

questions.text: What does Jimmy sell for a living?
questions.explanation:
Shoes.

	In the beginning of the episode, Jerry, George, and Kramer have just played a game of basketball at the gym with Jimmy.  Jimmy performed excellently because of his new plyometric shoes and George decides to buy a pair.  The group notices that it's odd that Jimmy always refers to himself in the third-person.

False.

	According to Kramer in this episode, he only takes cold showers.  This is confusing since Kramer said he only takes baths in an earlier episode.  George is nervous after playing basketball because he has to attend a meeting and he knows that he'll be sweating through the whole thing.  During the meeting, George's boss talks about a person stealing equipment from the Yankees and he begins to sweat profusely.

questions.text: What magazine is Jerry shocked to find in Tim Whatley's waiting room?
questions.explanation:
Penthouse.

	Jerry has to visit Tim Whatley for a dental appointment, and he finds that people are reading "Penthouse" magazines in the waiting room.  Jerry ends up having a cavity and needing to return for another appointment.  Kramer finds nothing wrong with the magazine issue.

questions.text: What performer does Elaine have tickets to see?
questions.explanation:
Mel Tormé.

	Elaine asks Jerry if he wants to see The Velvet Fog with her, but he doesn't like the idea of going to see a man sing because they get too emotional.  Elaine decides that she wants to ask the blonde guy at the gym for a date, but she ends up mistaking him for Jimmy because of the way that he talks in the third-person perspective.

questions.text: Who is responsible for Jimmy's injury at the gym?
questions.explanation:
Kramer.

	After returning from his dental appointment, Kramer's mouth is still filled with Novocain, so he finds it hard to move his mouth.  He tries drinking water, but he ends up drooling it all over the floor.  When Jimmy comes into the changing room, he slips on the water and hurts his back.

questions.text: What is the name of the man that Kramer shares a cab with?
questions.explanation:
Arnold.

	After leaving the gym, Kramer walks down the street wearing the Jimmy shoes.  He tries to hail a cab, but Arnold Deansfry arrives first and they decide to share the cab.  Because of the shoes and the Novocain, Arnold assumes that Kramer is mentally challenged, so he invites him as a special guest to the AMCA benefit.

questions.text: What is the name of Tim Whatley's assistant, when Jerry goes to his second appointment?
questions.explanation:
Cheryl.

	When Jerry goes to his second appointment, he finds Tim Whatley acting weird.  Whatley takes a whiff of the nitrous oxide before setting it up on Jerry and he tells him that occasionally, he and another doctor like to swap nurses once in a while.  When Jerry wakes up, he thinks that he sees Whatley and the nurse getting dressed.

questions.text: Who tells Elaine that she's dating the wrong guy?
options: No one.  She finds out on her own.
questions.explanation:
Jerry.

	At lunch, Jerry informs Elaine that she's stuck at the benefit with Jimmy because she never realized that he talks in the third-person.  Meanwhile, George is forced to pay for the equipment at work because he was sweating from eating Kung Pao chicken.  During lunch, Elaine and Jerry find that George seems to be turning into Jimmy.

questions.text: Jimmy is responsible for Kramer's swollen lip.
questions.explanation:
True.

	When Jimmy finds Kramer at the benefit, he fights him for revenge.  Jimmy manages to punch Kramer in the lip and it swells.  This causes Kramer to talk like he did with the Novocain after his dental appointment.  No one at the benefit seems to notice anything's wrong since it's a benefit for able mentally challenged adults.

questions.text: How does George get out of paying for new equipment?
options: By selling his shoes to the Yankees
questions.explanation:
By speaking in third-person.

	George ends up speaking entirely in third-person and his boss, George Steinbrenner, assumes that George is talking about him.  In the end, Mel Tormé sings a song to Kramer at the benefit and Jerry reads a column in "Penthouse" about a dentist and begins to think that it all really happened.
